answers.author: Austin Abraham
answers.text:
Frederick County MD has 3 maintenance departments: Parks, Water/Sewer, and all other general government.  It is my opinion that Parks and general government maintenance can be successful either combined or separate.  Parks has many grounds-related maintenance tasks that relate directly to the operation of a park that generally to not translate to maintenance of general government buildings.  Having crews that can sweep parking lots, take care of ball fields, and assist with special events in a park...who can then at other times repair shelters and handle trash...seems to work well under parks supervision.  On the other hand, maintenance of HVAC systems in year-round buildings may be better handled by a larger Maintenance department.  In the past 2 years we formed a hybrid version, where our general government Maintenance department has responsbility for HVAC, plumbing and electrical in our parks, but parks maintenance staff handle carpentry, painting and custodial.  In Frederick County the Parks Division is also responsible for groundskeeping and snow removal at all general government properties as well as for Parks.  Feel free to contact me if you would like to discuss in more detail.  Austin Abraham, DIrector, Management Services Division, Frederick County, MD

answers.author: Tom Nosack
answers.text:
The City of Vancouver, WA has found that a central general fund maintenance organization is the most efficeint use of resources. Our parks department sets maintenance standards (customer), the public works grounds maintenance crews are responsible to determine how to best meet the standards. (Internal contractor). It seems t haev worked well over time, although it requires the Parks department to identify specific standards and make sure their contractor is maintaining them.

author: Pamela Muse
text:
An Alliance member is interested in learning the pros and cons of having one Maintenance Department/Division that handles all maintenance issues for the entire city.  That is, some cities have maintenance divisions under Parks & Rec and under Public Works, etc.    
1)  Do you have one department that handles all maintenance?    
2)  If so, which department it is in?  
3)  Do you have any insights you can share re: pros/cons of one department or multiple maintenance divisions?  
Your time and expertise are appreciated!    
Pamela Muse
Western Regional Director
Alliance for Innovation
1-888-468-6450
Pmuse@transformgov.org
title: Maint Division in Public Works or Park & Rec or Both?
